Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: I was texting my sister, promising her I’d meet her and her friends for dinner after the protest. She’d been asking me to join them more often, saying it would mean a lot if I made an effort to be part of her world. I wanted to show her I respected her life as much as she tried to understand mine. But as I was about to leave, shouts rippled through the crowd. Police had started blocking the exits, and panic was spreading. My phone buzzed—my sister, asking if I was on my way. I could almost hear her disappointment if I bailed again. But as an organizer, people were looking to me for guidance, waiting for instructions to stay safe. My heart pounded. I felt torn in two—my sister’s trust on one side, the safety of my fellow activists on the other. I stared at my phone, caught between the promise I’d made and the responsibility I couldn’t ignore, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in.
